The LADAL is a collaborative effort that is sponsored by the School of Languages and Cultures at The University of Queensland, Australia. If you are interested in becoming an affiliate member or even a contributor contact the LADAL team via email (ladal\@uq.edu.au).

***

# DIRECTORS{-}

[Michael Haugh ](https://languages-cultures.uq.edu.au/profile/1498/michael-haugh)

```{r michael, echo=FALSE, out.width= "20%", out.extra='style="float:left; padding:10px"'}
knitr::include_graphics("images/michaelhaugh.jpeg")
```


+ Professor of Linguistics and Head of the School of Languages and Cultures. 

+ supervising the activities of LADAL 

+ promoting LADAL and its activities across Australia. 

Michael's research interests lie primarily in the field of pragmatics, with a focus on analysing face, (im)politeness, teasing and humour, indirectness, and intention. He has been involved in the establishment of the [Australian National Corpus](http://www.ausnc.org.au), and is interested in further developing methods in corpus-assisted pragmatics.  
  
  
[Martin Schweinberger](https://languages-cultures.uq.edu.au/profile/4295/martin-schweinberger)

```{r martin, echo=FALSE, out.width= "23%", out.extra='style="float:left; padding:10px"'}
knitr::include_graphics("images/martinschweinberger.jpeg")
```

+ Postdoctoral research fellow in Language Technology with a PhD in English linguistics at the School of Languages and Cultures where he has established LADAL

+ Language data scientist  specialized in corpus linguistics, quantitative analyses, computational modeling, and visualization of linguistic data. 

+ creating content, supervising team members, and directing the activities at LADAL 

His research focuses on language variation and change, determinants of language use and linguistic variability, as well as language acquisition.
